ATHENS: ARCH OF HADRIAN. View of the Arch of Hadrian, erected c130 A. D. in Athens, Greece. Copper engraving, 18th century

ATHENS: ARCH OF HADRIAN. View of the Arch of Hadrian, erected c130 A.D. in Athens, Greece. Copper engraving, 18th century

Media ID 7552679

2nd Century Arch Archaeology Athens Emperor Roman Ruin Hadrian

EDITORS COMMENTS

This print showcases the magnificent Arch of Hadrian, a testament to ancient Roman architecture and history. Erected around 130 A. D. in Athens, Greece, this arch stands as a symbol of power and grandeur. The copper engraving from the 18th century beautifully captures the intricate details and majesty of this ancient structure. The Arch of Hadrian is an exterior marvel that has withstood the test of time, serving as a reminder of its glorious past. Its archaeological significance cannot be overstated, offering valuable insights into the rich history and culture of ancient Rome. In this particular image, we are transported back to the 2nd century when men and women would have marveled at this architectural wonder. The landscape surrounding the arch adds to its allure, providing a picturesque backdrop for visitors then and now. Emperor Hadrian's influence can be felt through his namesake arch, showcasing his legacy as one of Rome's most prominent leaders. This print allows us to appreciate not only the craftsmanship but also the historical importance behind such structures. As part of The Granger Collection's art on demand collection, this print offers viewers an opportunity to bring home a piece of history while immersing themselves in awe-inspiring archaeology.
